Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue suppl_1, April 2017, Pages i63âi68, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqw048

div.p: Martin Holmes, Whatever happened to interchange?, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue suppl_1, April 2017, Pages i63âi68, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqw048

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: The adoption of XML and encoding standards such as those developed by the Text Encoding Initiative was accompanied by expectations of easy interoperability which are now widely seen as unfulfilled. The related but distinct concept of âinterchangeâ has received much less attention. This article argues that, particularly for sophisticated digital edition projects using XML, interchange is a more practical goal, and that approached in a specific way, it is highly beneficial not only to potential end users of the projectâs data but also to the project itself.
The article illustrates specific strategies and approaches to enabling and facilitating interchange, using work undertaken on the Map of Early Modern London (MoEML) project as a case study.

div.p: In his 2011 paper at the Balisage conference, Syd Bauman (2011) draws a clear and useful distinction between two terms which are often lazily conflated: âinteroperabilityâ and âinterchangeâ. Interoperability, he says, involves âlittle or no human interventionâ; data is pulled from one site or system and plugged unchanged into another. Interchange, on the other hand, involves human actions, either through direct communication between individuals or through indirect human mediation in which the re-user of data makes an effort to learn about it through reading documentation supplied with it, and then modifies or transforms it to put it to use in their own work.

The Text Encoding Initiative (TEI), as Unsworth (2011) points out, originally aimed at interchange rather than interoperability, with the âIâ in TEI standing in the Guidelines document itself for âInterchangeâ rather than âInitiativeâ. Perhaps because of the increasing range of big-data projects and tools looking for texts and corpora they can absorb and process, the focus nowadays is on interoperability and on the difficulties and failures we encounter with it (see, for example, McDonough, 2009 for a detailed discussion of the chequered history of interoperability in XML encoding standards used in libraries and archives). But interoperability is hard, especially in the case of literary and historical encoding projects with unique interests and research agendas producing densely encoded texts. The TEI schema is as large and complex as it is because its user community has a wide variety of precise requirements and the need to express them at different levels of specificity. As Bauman reminds us, âinteroperability and expressiveness are competing goals constantly in tension with each otherâ, and encoding with interoperability in mind is likely to produce results which are âsubstandard, less faithful to the document, or outright incorrectâ. We obviously do not want this; but when Schmidt (2014), to take one example, complains that âbecause the choice of tags is guided by human interpretation, TEI-XML encoded files are in general not interoperableâ, it is this very expressiveness he is complaining of.

In this article I would like to re-focus on interchange, for several reasons. Interchange is a common way for TEI files to be re-used, and this is especially common in teaching environments and among novice users. Despite this, other than insisting that detailed documentation is essential and expecting re-users to read that documentation, we do little in the way of encouraging and assisting in the re-use of our data. Paying more attention to the needs of users who might want to take and work with our TEI files has a number of significant benefits to the source project, not only in terms of ordinary documentation, but also with regard to clarifying, streamlining, and normalizing practices and schemas. Finally, I would argue that making sincere efforts to enhance the practicality of interchange actually contributes significantly towards enabling interoperability, the much harder problem. I will be primarily concerned with TEI digital edition projects here, but the principles involved are generalizable to any formal data structure.

A recent report on academic data sharing (Fecher et al., 2014) reveals that in the sciences, âdespite widespread support from policy makers, funding agencies, and scientific journals, academic researchers rarely make their research data available to othersâ (p. 1). The report finds a variety of reasons for this, including the effort required to make data available, a strong sense of ownership and desire for control, and the absence of compensation (pp. 12â15). There is no reason to believe that the situation is much better in the Humanities, despite recent shifts in policy by granting agencies and a widespread acknowledgement that an open data-sharing culture is an essential prerequisite for the establishment of Digital Humanities as a serious discipline (Borgman, 2009). If we share our XML at all (and many projects do not), we typically share one version of it: the version we created and customized to be as expressive, as faithful to the data, and as useful for the goals of our project as possible. On the face of it, the provision of a single unmediated version of our data is rather strange. Most modern web-based digital edition projects (to take one large subset of the XML encoding world) provide a wide variety of output formats, including various web views (for desktops and mobile devices), printable formats such as PDF, and even plain text. Interactive web views of documents often allow the user to choose between a variety of display optionsâTAPAS, for instance, allows the user to switch between diplomatic and normalized views, and between âTAPAS Genericâ and âTEI Boilerplateâ renderings.1 It is regarded as good practice to try to predict the variety of users who will visit a project, and to answer their needs as flexibly as possible. And yet, when it comes to our XML data, we do not do this; we typically provide a single XML dump for a document (in the TAPAS case, âDownload TEIâ).

In most projects, this XML view is likely to be full of peculiarities of encoding, rarely-used elements and attributes, intra-project links, and other features which, even if well-documented, will present barriers to re-use. A brief analysis of the encoding in our MoEML project shows many such issues, from which I examine three:

Complex encoding of dates with custom dating attributes:2
<date notBefore-custom=â1438-08-31â notAfter-custom=â1439-08-30â datingMethod=âmol:julianâ calendar=âmol:regnalâ>17thof
<name ref=âmol:HENR2â>Henry VI</name > </date> Use of many project-specific private URI schemes for linking:
<pb facs=âmoleebo:13311|2â/> Standoff mark-up in the form of pointers to personographies, taxonomies, etc. in other files within the project:
<l>The honour due by graue Antiquitie, </l > <l>Then giuen to <ref target=âmol:LOND5â>London </ref>s
<name ref=âmol:DRAP3â type=âorgâ>Draperie</name>,</l > <l>By Royall <name ref=âmol:RICH2â>Richard</name>, who in me,</l> All of these encoding practices are perfectly reasonable, and are well-documented both by the project and in the TEI Guidelines (TEI Consortium, 2015), but they are likely to stand in the way of scholars wishing to take one of our documents out of its surrounding infrastructure and work with it in another context. The solution is obvious: in all of these cases, we can replace the problem feature with a more common encoding. For example, to make our date encoding more broadly useful, we could easily convert the date from the Julian calendar to the proleptic Gregorian, and remove the @datingMethod attribute:
<date notBefore=â1438-09-09â notAfter=â1439-09-08â calendar=âmol:regnalâ>17th of
<name ref=âmol:HENR2â>Henry VI</name > </date> Similarly, we can expand the private URI schemes into full URLs, so that âmoleebo:13311|2â becomes:
<pb facs=âhttp://eebo.chadwyck.com/fetchimage?vid=13311&page=2&width=1200â/> With strategies such as these, we generate what we refer to as our âStandardâ output format which eschews unusual project-specific encoding practices.

Intra-project links to personographies, gazetteers, bibliographical references, and similar resources can be expanded in similar ways. However, many users will prefer a version of the document which does not depend on resources in linked files. We can provide for this by importing external resources into the appropriate locations in the host document, creating for example a <particDesc> containing a <listPerson> in the header, and a <listBibl> for a bibliography in the <back>.

In this way, we can create a complete, âStandaloneâ version of the encoded document which, in addition to the advantages of the âStandardâ version, has no external dependencies. The result is coherent, portable, and much easier to re-use outside the project context.

Producing a more standardized and self-contained document is one step on the path to effective interchange, but it will be useful only to a subset of potential users. The TEI schema, even if we restrict ourselves to the more common encoding practices, is still huge and daunting particularly to novice users, and problematic for the tools they are likely to use (TEI stylesheets, collation tools, rendering tools such as TEI Boilerplate,3 and so on). We can go further by providing output in simpler, more constrained versions of TEI, such as TEI Lite4 or the nascent TEI Simple.5

Naturally, there are trade-offs here. We might characterize such conversions as lossy downsampling; most highly expressive project-specific encoding strategies will suffer in the translation to a much simpler and more constrained format. For example, the current version of the TEI Simple proposal (Rahtz, 2014) states that âWe will preclude use of @rend and @styleâ, and âWe will produce a closed list of values for @rendition using a pseudo-protocol of âsimple:ââ. The MoEML project uses @style and @rendition extensively with CSS code to describe the appearance, layout, and typography of primary source documents. Converting this to TEI Simple requires an additional processing step which analyses that CSS code and converts it to the nearest possible representation in the limited token set provided by Simple,6 discarding information which cannot be represented. Similarly, Simple (currently) lacks the <mentioned> element, which we use extensively; this has to be mapped to a more generic representation such as <seg type=âmentionedâ>.

This is an uncomfortable prospect, perhaps, but it does have some positive aspects. First of all, it causes us to evaluate all our encoding practices and to consider whether we really do need to use a particular formulation when something plainer might do. Secondly, downsampling or simplification in the process of rendering into a widely used constrained format constitutes what we might call âenacted documentationâ; by mapping our encoding to a simpler representation, we provide another level of description of our encoding practice. For example, this template, part of a conversion to TEI Lite, shows how the <supplied> element, not present in TEI Lite, is replaced with a <seg> element, documenting in the process not only how the output is produced but how the MoEML project typically uses <supplied> and its attributes:
<!â No <supplied>. Have to make do with <seg>. â>
<xsl:template match=âsuppliedâ>
<seg type=âsuppliedâ n=â{concat(@reason, if(@evidence) then concat(â²; evidence: â², @evidence) else â²â²)}â>
<xsl:apply-templates select=â@*|node()â/>
</seg>
</xsl:template> It might seem that such conversion processes should be undertaken by the end user, not the source project. However, in dealing with unusual encoding practices or rare elements and attributes, the source projectâs encoders will have a much better understanding of what is intended, and how best to represent it in the target output. The example above, for instance, shows that in MoEML documents, <supplied> can be assumed always to bear the @reason attribute, and often also @evidence. An outsider coming to the project may not be willing or able to undertake the work involved in reading the project documentation and building an appropriate transformation such as this, and even worse, an automated tool may simply throw away important information without comment. For instance, the Abbot Text Interoperability Tool,7 in converting our project praxis documents to TEI Lite, simply throws away without comment all of the <egXML> elements which usually constitute the focus of the discussion in each document; in fact, the <egXML> element is available in TEI Lite, and even without it, these examples could be represented quite well using the <eg> element. When lossy conversions are written by the progenitors of a projectâs data, they are likely to be considerably less lossy.

In targeting particular output formats, we are implicitly targeting specific user groups (albeit rather generic ones; TEI Lite is intended to âmeet 90% of the needs of 90% of the TEI user communityâ,8 while TEI Simple âaims to define a new highly-constrained and prescriptive subset of the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI) Guidelines suited to the representation of early modern and modern booksâ9). It is difficult to predict who the end users of a project's interchange XML might be and what particular needs they might have, but every project will have some familiarity with its user base and some specific concerns which can inform decisions relating to the range of output formats which might be provided. For example, the MoEML project has a special interest in digital pedagogy and in training encoders;10 our Standard output format provides helpful models for introductory XML encoding workshops, while the Standalone versions are useful for teaching XPath and basic XSLT. The Lite and Simple outputs are more likely to function effectively with generic TEI publication engines and tools such as TAPAS and TEI Boilerplate, supporting our commitment to encouraging re-use of our encoded texts.

While it has been argued that TEI-XML has not lived up to its early promise with regard to interoperability, the focus on interoperability (unmediated re-use) has largely eclipsed interchange (human-mediated re-use), which is far more practical in most cases. At the same time, the assumption that the mediation (i.e. processing) involved in interchange should be the responsibility of the end user rather than the source project can be seen as a significant barrier to re-use. By putting some effort into providing a range of different versions of our XML source encodings, targeted at different use-cases and user groups, we can greatly facilitate the re-use of our data in other projects; this process causes beneficial reflection on our own encoding practices, as well as an additional layer of documentation for our projects. Furthermore, by generating specific highly constrained output formats such as TEI Simple, we also help to facilitate interoperability.

In the MoEML project, we have enhanced the variety of XML renderings of our documents, and now provide five different views: âOriginalâ, âStandardâ, âStandaloneâ TEI Lite and TEI Simple; see the XML menu in Fig. 1, taken from http://mapoflondon.uvic.ca/METR1.htm.

img.alt: The menu of downloadable XML versions from the MoEML site

div.p: The menu of downloadable XML versions from the MoEML site

img.alt: The menu of downloadable XML versions from the MoEML site

div.p: The menu of downloadable XML versions from the MoEML site

At the time of writing, the TEI Simple schema has not yet been added to the official set of TEI-supported customizations, so we expect to make further updates to this particular transformation in the near future as the Simple project stabilizes. A further documentation page11 provides an explanation of how each of these formats is derived, and suggests what kind of end-use it might be appropriate for. We are aiming to present a model example of how we might stimulate interchange and contribute to interoperability. Based on the demonstrable value of outputs created specifically for interchange, I would argue that such outputs should be incorporated as a formal component of plans and grant applications for all digital edition projects, and that granting agencies should be encouraged to look for and value this factor in project plans.

The Map of Early Modern London project was supported by an Insight Grant (2012â16) from the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada, and currently forms part of an umbrella project, Endings, which is also funded by SSHRC (2016â19). Prior and other funding and support is detailed on http://mapoflondon.uvic.ca/acknowledgements.htm.
1 See, for example, http://tapasproject.org/digital-mitford/lettertotntalfourd28oct1821/16145.
2 See Holmes, Jenstad and Butt 2013 for an argument that sophisticated encoding of historical dates is essential for some types of interoperability.
3 http://teiboilerplate.org/.
4 http://www.tei-c.org/Guidelines/Customization/Lite/.
5 https://github.com/TEIC/TEI-Simple.
6 A set of thirty-six (at the time of writing) tokens such as simple:allcaps and simple:blackletter, as documented at https://github.com/TEIC/TEI-Simple/blob/master/teisimple.html.
7 http://abbot.unl.edu/cocoon/vicar/Vicar.html.
8 http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-exemplars/html/tei_lite.doc.html.
9 https://github.com/TEIC/TEI-Simple.
10 http://mapoflondon.uvic.ca/teaching.htm.
11 http://mapoflondon.uvic.ca/xml_outputs.htm.
